title: Families of Three Uvalde Shooting Survivors Sue School District, Gun Manufacturers, Others; Civil lawsuit, filed in federal court, seeks damages for the three survivors
text:
The lawsuit asks for damages for the families, the amount of which would be determined through a trial by jury.

The mass shooting at Robb Elementary School this spring was the deadliest at a U.S. school since the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newton, Conn., in 2012. The massacre—and the delayed response by law enforcement—left the local community reeling.

A recent review by Texas lawmakers found systematic failures by hundreds of armed law-enforcement officers led to their delayed confrontation with the shooter, potentially costing lives. A team of Border Patrol agents confronted and killed the 18-year-old gunman more than an hour after police began to arrive, according to the report.

The school board in Uvalde voted unanimously in August to fire district Police Chief Pete Arredondo, who oversaw the heavily criticized response to the mass shooting. Before the meeting, Mr. Arredondo's lawyer released a statement describing his client's conduct during the shooting as outstanding and accusing the district of blocking his ability to clear his name.

The lawsuit filed this week named 10 defendants, including Mr. Arredondo, the Uvalde Consolidated Independent School District, the city, the acting chief of the Uvalde Police Department at the time of the shooting, the elementary school's former principal, as well as gun manufacturers and a gun dealer, among others.

It alleges that Daniel Defense LLC, identified as the manufacturer of the gun used in the shooting, uses deceptive and reckless marketing to attract young, untrained adults. A representative for Daniel Defense didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.

The lawsuit argues Daniel Defense and other gun-industry defendants "violated federal law by negligently entrusting their deadly weapons to the Uvalde school shooter."

Gun manufacturers have broad protections under federal law from lawsuits brought against them over the illegal use of their products. But it may be possible for manufacturers to be found liable based on marketing tactics that violate state law.

The lawsuit also named Schneider Electric USA Inc., which the complaint said manufactured the door-locking mechanisms for classrooms at the elementary school. The lawsuit said the doors "failed to lock as designed after being shut."

"What happened in Uvalde was an unspeakable tragedy that we condemn in the strongest terms," a spokesman for the company said. "We are reviewing this recent filing but cannot comment further on pending litigation."

The lawsuit was filed by the families of three students at Robb Elementary who were there on the day of the shooting. One of the children, identified in the lawsuit as G.M., was in fourth grade at the time. He was shot in his right leg, and his teachers and best friend were killed, according to the lawsuit.

"Prior to the shooting, G.M. told his best friend's mother he would always protect his best friend," the complaint said. "Tearfully, he told her after, he was sorry he couldn't."

The suit comes as students and teachers in the Texas town begin school again, three months after the massacre.

"These kids just came back to school, and we are already hearing that many of them are scared for their lives," said Monique Alarcon, one of the attorneys at Baum Hedlund Aristei & Goldman representing the families, in a statement Thursday. "It's clear that this unspeakable trauma will be with them for a long time, perhaps for the rest of their lives. This case is about ensuring that they have access to the care and resources they need."
